trans-unit.source: Create a REST service using ASP.NET Web API and SQL Database in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create a REST service using ASP.NET Web API and SQL Database in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that teaches you how to deploy an app that uses the ASP.NET Web API to an Azure web app by using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that teaches you how to deploy an app that uses the ASP.NET Web API to an Azure web app by using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Create a REST service using ASP.NET Web API and SQL Database in Azure App Service
trans-unit.target: Create a REST service using ASP.NET Web API and SQL Database in Azure App Service

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to deploy an ASP.NET web app to an [Azure App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) by using the Publish Web wizard in Visual Studio 2013 or Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to deploy an ASP.NET web app to an [Azure App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714) by using the Publish Web wizard in Visual Studio 2013 or Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.

trans-unit.source: You can open an Azure account for free, and if you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK automatically installs Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.
trans-unit.target: You can open an Azure account for free, and if you don't already have Visual Studio 2013, the SDK automatically installs Visual Studio 2013 for Web Express.

trans-unit.source: So you can start developing for Azure entirely for free.
trans-unit.target: So you can start developing for Azure entirely for free.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience using Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have no prior experience using Azure.

trans-unit.source: On completing this tutorial, you'll have a simple web app up and running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: On completing this tutorial, you'll have a simple web app up and running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: You'll learn:
trans-unit.target: You'll learn:

trans-unit.source: How to enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: How to enable your machine for Azure development by installing the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: How to create a Visual Studio ASP.NET MVC 5 project and publish it to an Azure app.
trans-unit.target: How to create a Visual Studio ASP.NET MVC 5 project and publish it to an Azure app.

trans-unit.source: How to use the ASP.NET Web API to enable Restful API calls.
trans-unit.target: How to use the ASP.NET Web API to enable Restful API calls.

trans-unit.source: How to use a SQL database to store data in Azure.
trans-unit.target: How to use a SQL database to store data in Azure.

trans-unit.source: How to publish application updates to Azure.
trans-unit.target: How to publish application updates to Azure.

trans-unit.source: You'll build a simple contact list web application that is built on ASP.NET MVC 5 and uses the ADO.NET Entity Framework for database access.
trans-unit.target: You'll build a simple contact list web application that is built on ASP.NET MVC 5 and uses the ADO.NET Entity Framework for database access.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows the completed application:
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows the completed application:

trans-unit.source: screenshot of web site
trans-unit.target: screenshot of web site

trans-unit.source: Create the project
trans-unit.target: Create the project

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: From the **File** menu click **New Project**.
trans-unit.target: From the **File** menu click **New Project**.

trans-unit.source: In the **New Project** dialog box, expand **Visual C#** and select **Web** and then select **ASP.NET MVC 5 Web Application**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New Project** dialog box, expand **Visual C#** and select **Web** and then select **ASP.NET MVC 5 Web Application**.

trans-unit.source: Name the application **ContactManager** and click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Name the application **ContactManager** and click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: New Project dialog box
trans-unit.target: New Project dialog box

trans-unit.source: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, select the **MVC** template, check **Web API** and then click **Change Authentication**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, select the **MVC** template, check **Web API** and then click **Change Authentication**.

trans-unit.source: New ASP.NET Project dialog box
trans-unit.target: New ASP.NET Project dialog box

trans-unit.source: In the **Change Authentication** dialog box, click **No Authentication**, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Change Authentication** dialog box, click **No Authentication**, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: No Authentication
trans-unit.target: No Authentication

trans-unit.source: The sample application you're creating won't have features that require users to log in.
trans-unit.target: The sample application you're creating won't have features that require users to log in.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to implement authentication and authorization features, see the [Next Steps](#nextsteps) section at the end of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to implement authentication and authorization features, see the [Next Steps](#nextsteps) section at the end of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: In the **New ASP.NET Project** dialog box, click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: New ASP.NET Project dialog box
trans-unit.target: New ASP.NET Project dialog box

trans-unit.source: If you have not previously signed in to Azure, you will be prompted to sign in.
trans-unit.target: If you have not previously signed in to Azure, you will be prompted to sign in.

trans-unit.source: The configuration wizard will suggest a unique name based on *ContactManager* (see the image below).
trans-unit.target: The configuration wizard will suggest a unique name based on *ContactManager* (see the image below).

trans-unit.source: Select a region near you.
trans-unit.target: Select a region near you.

trans-unit.source: You can use [azurespeed.com](http://www.azurespeed.com/ "AzureSpeed.com") to find the lowest latency data center.
trans-unit.target: You can use [azurespeed.com](http://www.azurespeed.com/ "AzureSpeed.com") to find the lowest latency data center.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't created a database server before, select **Create new server**, enter a database user name and password.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't created a database server before, select **Create new server**, enter a database user name and password.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure Website
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure Website

trans-unit.source: If you have a database server, use that to create a new database.
trans-unit.target: If you have a database server, use that to create a new database.

trans-unit.source: Database servers are a precious resource, and you generally want to create multiple databases on the same server for testing and development rather than creating a database server per database.
trans-unit.target: Database servers are a precious resource, and you generally want to create multiple databases on the same server for testing and development rather than creating a database server per database.

trans-unit.source: Make sure your web site and database are in the same region.
trans-unit.target: Make sure your web site and database are in the same region.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure Website
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure Website

trans-unit.source: Set the page header and footer
trans-unit.target: Set the page header and footer

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, expand the *Views\Shared* folder and open the *_Layout.cshtml* file.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, expand the *Views\Shared* folder and open the *_Layout.cshtml* file.

trans-unit.source: _Layout.cshtml in Solution Explorer
trans-unit.target: _Layout.cshtml in Solution Explorer

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the *Views\Shared_Layout.cshtml* file with the following code:
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the *Views\Shared_Layout.cshtml* file with the following code:

trans-unit.source: The markup above changes the app name from "My ASP.NET App" to "Contact Manager", and it removes the links to **Home**, **About** and **Contact**.
trans-unit.target: The markup above changes the app name from "My ASP.NET App" to "Contact Manager", and it removes the links to **Home**, **About** and **Contact**.

trans-unit.source: Run the application locally
trans-unit.target: Run the application locally

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: The application home page appears in the default browser.
trans-unit.target: The application home page appears in the default browser.

trans-unit.source: To Do List home page
trans-unit.target: To Do List home page

trans-unit.source: This is all you need to do for now to create the application that you'll deploy to Azure.
trans-unit.target: This is all you need to do for now to create the application that you'll deploy to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Later you'll add database functionality.
trans-unit.target: Later you'll add database functionality.

trans-unit.source: Deploy the application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy the application to Azure

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in **Solution Explorer** and select **Publish** from the context menu.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the project in **Solution Explorer** and select **Publish** from the context menu.

trans-unit.source: Publish in project context menu
trans-unit.target: Publish in project context menu

trans-unit.source: The **Publish Web** wizard opens.
trans-unit.target: The **Publish Web** wizard opens.

trans-unit.source: Click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Settings tab
trans-unit.target: Settings tab

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio begins the process of copying the files to the Azure server.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio begins the process of copying the files to the Azure server.

trans-unit.source: The **Output** window shows what deployment actions were taken and reports successful completion of the deployment.
trans-unit.target: The **Output** window shows what deployment actions were taken and reports successful completion of the deployment.

trans-unit.source: The default browser automatically opens to the URL of the deployed site.
trans-unit.target: The default browser automatically opens to the URL of the deployed site.

trans-unit.source: The application you created is now running in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The application you created is now running in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: To Do List home page running in Azure
trans-unit.target: To Do List home page running in Azure

trans-unit.source: Add a database to the application
trans-unit.target: Add a database to the application

trans-unit.source: Next, you'll update the MVC application to add the ability to display and update contacts and store the data in a database.
trans-unit.target: Next, you'll update the MVC application to add the ability to display and update contacts and store the data in a database.

trans-unit.source: The application will use the Entity Framework to create the database and to read and update data in the database.
trans-unit.target: The application will use the Entity Framework to create the database and to read and update data in the database.

trans-unit.source: Add data model classes for the contacts
trans-unit.target: Add data model classes for the contacts

trans-unit.source: You begin by creating a simple data model in code.
trans-unit.target: You begin by creating a simple data model in code.

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, right-click the Models folder, click **Add**, and then **Class**.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, right-click the Models folder, click **Add**, and then **Class**.

trans-unit.source: Add Class in Models folder context menu
trans-unit.target: Add Class in Models folder context menu

trans-unit.source: In the **Add New Item** dialog box, name the new class file *Contact.cs*, and then click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Add New Item** dialog box, name the new class file *Contact.cs*, and then click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Add New Item dialog box
trans-unit.target: Add New Item dialog box

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the Contacts.cs file with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the Contacts.cs file with the following code.

trans-unit.source: The **Contacts** class defines the data that you will store for each contact, plus a primary key, ContactID, that is needed by the database.
trans-unit.target: The **Contacts** class defines the data that you will store for each contact, plus a primary key, ContactID, that is needed by the database.

trans-unit.source: You can get more information about data models in the [Next Steps](#nextsteps) section at the end of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You can get more information about data models in the [Next Steps](#nextsteps) section at the end of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Create web pages that enable app users to work with the contacts
trans-unit.target: Create web pages that enable app users to work with the contacts

trans-unit.source: The ASP.NET MVC the scaffolding feature can automatically generate code that performs create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) actions.
trans-unit.target: The ASP.NET MVC the scaffolding feature can automatically generate code that performs create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) actions.

trans-unit.source: Add a Controller and a view for the data
trans-unit.target: Add a Controller and a view for the data

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, expand the Controllers folder.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, expand the Controllers folder.

trans-unit.source: Build the project **(Ctrl+Shift+B)**.
trans-unit.target: Build the project **(Ctrl+Shift+B)**.

trans-unit.source: (You must build the project before using scaffolding mechanism.)
trans-unit.target: (You must build the project before using scaffolding mechanism.)

trans-unit.source: Right-click the Controllers folder and click **Add**, and then click **Controller**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the Controllers folder and click **Add**, and then click **Controller**.

trans-unit.source: Add Controller in Controllers folder context menu
trans-unit.target: Add Controller in Controllers folder context menu

trans-unit.source: In the **Add Scaffold** dialog box, select **MVC Controller with views, using Entity Framework** and click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Add Scaffold** dialog box, select **MVC Controller with views, using Entity Framework** and click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Add controller
trans-unit.target: Add controller

trans-unit.source: Set the controller name to **HomeController**.
trans-unit.target: Set the controller name to **HomeController**.

trans-unit.source: Select **Contact** as your model class.
trans-unit.target: Select **Contact** as your model class.

trans-unit.source: Click the **New data context** button and accept the default "ContactManager.Models.ContactManagerContext" for the **New data context type**.
trans-unit.target: Click the **New data context** button and accept the default "ContactManager.Models.ContactManagerContext" for the **New data context type**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Add**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Add**.

trans-unit.source: Add Controller dialog box
trans-unit.target: Add Controller dialog box

trans-unit.source: A dialog box will prompt you: "A file with the name HomeController already exits.
trans-unit.target: A dialog box will prompt you: "A file with the name HomeController already exits.

trans-unit.source: Do you want to replace it?".
trans-unit.target: Do you want to replace it?".

trans-unit.source: Click **Yes**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Yes**.

trans-unit.source: We are overwriting the Home Controller that was created with the new project.
trans-unit.target: We are overwriting the Home Controller that was created with the new project.

trans-unit.source: We will use the new Home Controller for our contact list.
trans-unit.target: We will use the new Home Controller for our contact list.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio creates a controller methods and views for CRUD database operations for **Contact** objects.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio creates a controller methods and views for CRUD database operations for **Contact** objects.

trans-unit.source: Enable Migrations, create the database, add sample data and a data initializer
trans-unit.target: Enable Migrations, create the database, add sample data and a data initializer

trans-unit.source: The next task is to enable the [Code First Migrations](http://curah.microsoft.com/55220) feature in order to create the database based on the data model you created.
trans-unit.target: The next task is to enable the [Code First Migrations](http://curah.microsoft.com/55220) feature in order to create the database based on the data model you created.

trans-unit.source: In the **Tools** menu, select **Library Package Manager** and then **Package Manager Console**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Tools** menu, select **Library Package Manager** and then **Package Manager Console**.

trans-unit.source: Package Manager Console in Tools menu
trans-unit.target: Package Manager Console in Tools menu

trans-unit.source: In the **Package Manager Console** window, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: In the **Package Manager Console** window, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The **enable-migrations** command creates a *Migrations* folder and it puts in that folder a *Configuration.cs* file that you can edit to configure Migrations.
trans-unit.target: The **enable-migrations** command creates a *Migrations* folder and it puts in that folder a *Configuration.cs* file that you can edit to configure Migrations.

trans-unit.source: In the **Package Manager Console** window, enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: In the **Package Manager Console** window, enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The **add-migration Initial** command generates a class named **<date_stamp>Initial** that creates the database.
trans-unit.target: The **add-migration Initial** command generates a class named **<date_stamp>Initial** that creates the database.

trans-unit.source: The first parameter ( *Initial* ) is arbitrary and used to create the name of the file.
trans-unit.target: The first parameter ( *Initial* ) is arbitrary and used to create the name of the file.

trans-unit.source: You can see the new class files in **Solution Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: You can see the new class files in **Solution Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Initial** class, the **Up** method creates the Contacts table, and the **Down** method (used when you want to return to the previous state) drops it.
trans-unit.target: In the **Initial** class, the **Up** method creates the Contacts table, and the **Down** method (used when you want to return to the previous state) drops it.

trans-unit.source: Open the *Migrations\Configuration.cs* file.
trans-unit.target: Open the *Migrations\Configuration.cs* file.

trans-unit.source: Add XSRF Protection
trans-unit.target: Add XSRF Protection

trans-unit.source: Cross-site request forgery (also known as XSRF or CSRF) is an attack against web-hosted applications whereby a malicious website can influence the interaction between a client browser and a website trusted by that browser.
trans-unit.target: Cross-site request forgery (also known as XSRF or CSRF) is an attack against web-hosted applications whereby a malicious website can influence the interaction between a client browser and a website trusted by that browser.

trans-unit.source: These attacks are made possible because web browsers will send authentication tokens automatically with every request to a website.
trans-unit.target: These attacks are made possible because web browsers will send authentication tokens automatically with every request to a website.

trans-unit.source: The canonical example is an authentication cookie, such as ASP.NET's Forms Authentication ticket.
trans-unit.target: The canonical example is an authentication cookie, such as ASP.NET's Forms Authentication ticket.

trans-unit.source: However, websites which use any persistent authentication mechanism (such as Windows Authentication, Basic, and so forth) can be targeted by these attacks.
trans-unit.target: However, websites which use any persistent authentication mechanism (such as Windows Authentication, Basic, and so forth) can be targeted by these attacks.

trans-unit.source: An XSRF attack is distinct from a phishing attack.
trans-unit.target: An XSRF attack is distinct from a phishing attack.

trans-unit.source: Phishing attacks require interaction from the victim.
trans-unit.target: Phishing attacks require interaction from the victim.

trans-unit.source: In a phishing attack, a malicious website will mimic the target website, and the victim is fooled into providing sensitive information to the attacker.
trans-unit.target: In a phishing attack, a malicious website will mimic the target website, and the victim is fooled into providing sensitive information to the attacker.

trans-unit.source: In an XSRF attack, there is often no interaction necessary from the victim.
trans-unit.target: In an XSRF attack, there is often no interaction necessary from the victim.

trans-unit.source: Rather, the attacker is relying on the browser automatically sending all relevant cookies to the destination website.
trans-unit.target: Rather, the attacker is relying on the browser automatically sending all relevant cookies to the destination website.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the [Open Web Application Security Project](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Main_Page) (OWASP) [XSRF](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the [Open Web Application Security Project](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Main_Page) (OWASP) [XSRF](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-Site_Request_Forgery_(CSRF)).

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, right **ContactManager** project and click **Add** and then click **Class**.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, right **ContactManager** project and click **Add** and then click **Class**.

trans-unit.source: Name the file *ValidateHttpAntiForgeryTokenAttribute.cs* and add the following code:
trans-unit.target: Name the file *ValidateHttpAntiForgeryTokenAttribute.cs* and add the following code:

trans-unit.source: Add the following *using* statement to the contracts controller so you have access to the **[ValidateHttpAntiForgeryToken]** attribute.
trans-unit.target: Add the following *using* statement to the contracts controller so you have access to the **[ValidateHttpAntiForgeryToken]** attribute.

trans-unit.source: using ContactManager.Filters;
trans-unit.target: using ContactManager.Filters;

trans-unit.source: Add the **[ValidateHttpAntiForgeryToken]** attribute to the Post methods of the **ContactsController** to protect it from XSRF threats.
trans-unit.target: Add the **[ValidateHttpAntiForgeryToken]** attribute to the Post methods of the **ContactsController** to protect it from XSRF threats.

trans-unit.source: You will add it to the "PutContact", "PostContact" and **DeleteContact** action methods.
trans-unit.target: You will add it to the "PutContact", "PostContact" and **DeleteContact** action methods.

trans-unit.source: [ValidateHttpAntiForgeryToken]
trans-unit.target: [ValidateHttpAntiForgeryToken]

trans-unit.source: public IHttpActionResult PutContact(int id, Contact contact)
trans-unit.target: public IHttpActionResult PutContact(int id, Contact contact)

trans-unit.source: Update the *Scripts* section of the *Views\Home\Index.cshtml* file to include code to get the XSRF tokens.
trans-unit.target: Update the *Scripts* section of the *Views\Home\Index.cshtml* file to include code to get the XSRF tokens.

trans-unit.source: Publish the application update to Azure and SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Publish the application update to Azure and SQL Database

trans-unit.source: To publish the application, you repeat the procedure you followed earlier.
trans-unit.target: To publish the application, you repeat the procedure you followed earlier.

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, right click the project and select **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, right click the project and select **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: Publish
trans-unit.target: Publish

trans-unit.source: Click the **Settings** tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the **Settings** tab.

trans-unit.source: Under **ContactsManagerContext(ContactsManagerContext)**, click the **v** icon to change *Remote connection string* to the connection string for the contact database.
trans-unit.target: Under **ContactsManagerContext(ContactsManagerContext)**, click the **v** icon to change *Remote connection string* to the connection string for the contact database.

trans-unit.source: Click **ContactDB**.
trans-unit.target: Click **ContactDB**.

trans-unit.source: Settings
trans-unit.target: Settings

trans-unit.source: Check the box for **Execute Code First Migrations (runs on application start)**.
trans-unit.target: Check the box for **Execute Code First Migrations (runs on application start)**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Next** and then click **Preview**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Next** and then click **Preview**.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio displays a list of the files that will be added or updated.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio displays a list of the files that will be added or updated.

trans-unit.source: Click **Publish**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Publish**.

trans-unit.source: After the deployment completes, the browser opens to the home page of the application.
trans-unit.target: After the deployment completes, the browser opens to the home page of the application.

trans-unit.source: Index page with no contacts
trans-unit.target: Index page with no contacts

trans-unit.source: The Visual Studio publish process automatically configured the connection string in the deployed *Web.config* file to point to the SQL database.
trans-unit.target: The Visual Studio publish process automatically configured the connection string in the deployed *Web.config* file to point to the SQL database.

trans-unit.source: It also configured Code First Migrations to automatically upgrade the database to the latest version the first time the application accesses the database after deployment.
trans-unit.target: It also configured Code First Migrations to automatically upgrade the database to the latest version the first time the application accesses the database after deployment.

trans-unit.source: As a result of this configuration, Code First created the database by running the code in the **Initial** class that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: As a result of this configuration, Code First created the database by running the code in the **Initial** class that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: It did this the first time the application tried to access the database after deployment.
trans-unit.target: It did this the first time the application tried to access the database after deployment.

trans-unit.source: Enter a contact as you did when you ran the app locally, to verify that database deployment succeeded.
trans-unit.target: Enter a contact as you did when you ran the app locally, to verify that database deployment succeeded.

trans-unit.source: When you see that the item you enter is saved and appears on the contact manager page, you know that it has been stored in the database.
trans-unit.target: When you see that the item you enter is saved and appears on the contact manager page, you know that it has been stored in the database.

trans-unit.source: Index page with contacts
trans-unit.target: Index page with contacts

trans-unit.source: The application is now running in the cloud, using SQL Database to store its data.
trans-unit.target: The application is now running in the cloud, using SQL Database to store its data.

trans-unit.source: After you finish testing the application in Azure, delete it.
trans-unit.target: After you finish testing the application in Azure, delete it.

trans-unit.source: The application is public and doesn't have a mechanism to limit access.
trans-unit.target: The application is public and doesn't have a mechanism to limit access.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Next Steps
trans-unit.target: Next Steps

trans-unit.source: A real application would require authentication and authorization, and you would use the membership database for that purpose.
trans-unit.target: A real application would require authentication and authorization, and you would use the membership database for that purpose.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial [Deploy a Secure ASP.NET MVC application with OAuth, Membership and SQL Database](web-sites-dotnet-deploy-aspnet-mvc-app-membership-oauth-sql-database.md) is based on this tutorial and shows how to deploy a web application with the membership database.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial [Deploy a Secure ASP.NET MVC application with OAuth, Membership and SQL Database](web-sites-dotnet-deploy-aspnet-mvc-app-membership-oauth-sql-database.md) is based on this tutorial and shows how to deploy a web application with the membership database.

trans-unit.source: Another way to store data in an Azure application is to use Azure storage, which provide non-relational data storage in the form of blobs and tables.
trans-unit.target: Another way to store data in an Azure application is to use Azure storage, which provide non-relational data storage in the form of blobs and tables.

trans-unit.target: This tutorial and the sample application was written by [Rick Anderson](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/rickandy/) (Twitter [@RickAndMSFT](https://twitter.com/RickAndMSFT)) with assistance from Tom Dykstra and Barry Dorrans (Twitter [@blowdart](https://twitter.com/blowdart)).

trans-unit.source: Please leave feedback on what you liked or what you would like to see improved, not only about the tutorial itself but also about the products that it demonstrates.
trans-unit.target: Please leave feedback on what you liked or what you would like to see improved, not only about the tutorial itself but also about the products that it demonstrates.

trans-unit.source: Your feedback will help us prioritize improvements.
trans-unit.target: Your feedback will help us prioritize improvements.

trans-unit.source: We are especially interested in finding out how much interest there is in more automation for the process of configuring and deploying the membership database.
trans-unit.target: We are especially interested in finding out how much interest there is in more automation for the process of configuring and deploying the membership database.
